DataElement.preferredName: Initial Pathologic Diagnosis Biopsy Confirmed Prior To Tumor Excision CPTAC Indicator
DataElement.preferredDefinition: An indicator response to document whether a biopsy confirmed the initial pathologic diagnosis prior to the surgical removal all or part of a benign or malignant tissue growth.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Initial Pathologic Diagnosis Biopsy Confirmed Prior To Tumor Excision
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A question about the method to obtain the initial pathologic diagnosis._The removal of tissue specimens or fluid from the living body for microscopic examination, performed to establish a diagnosis._Having been established or verified._Earlier in time or order._Used as a function word to indicate direction, purpose, or movement._A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias._The act of cutting out; the surgical removal of part or all of a structure or organ.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A question about the method to obtain the initial pathologic diagnosis.

Concepts.definition: A question about the method to obtain the initial pathologic diagnosis.

Property.preferredName: Biopsy Confirmation Prior To Neoplasm Excision
Property.preferredDefinition: The removal of tissue specimens or fluid from the living body for microscopic examination, performed to establish a diagnosis.:Having been established or verified.:Earlier in time or order.:Used as a function word to indicate direction, purpose, or movement.:A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.:The act of cutting out; the surgical removal of part or all of a structure or organ.

Concepts.definition: The removal of tissue specimens or fluid from the living body for microscopic examination, performed to establish a diagnosis.
Used as a function word to indicate direction, purpose, or movement.

A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.
The surgical removal of a lesion, often as part of a biopsy and with healthy margins.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).
